prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Views of transferee judge

para.paratext: In one case the Panel has considered a request by a transferee judge that cases be transferred by the Panel.[1] This factor is clearly an exceptional one, and is not routinely considered by the Panel.

The case in which this factor was considered involved a motion for reconsideration of the denial of a motion for transfer of six tag-along actions for coordinated or consolidated pre trial proceedings with 45 actions that had previously been transferred. The Panel relied on the fact that the transferee court had certified a class action after the motion for transfer of the tag-along actions was considered and that a tentative settlement of the class action had been reached in granting reconsideration. The Panel also relied on the transferee judge's letter to the Panel urging transfer of the tag-along actions. That letter stated in part:
It is entirely probable that the entire Bendectin Litigation will be settled. It would be administratively far easier to handle this matter if all cases were concentrated in this District.[2]

The likelihood of settlement as expressed by the transferee judge was logically given weight by the Panel. It is doubtful that the transferee judge's views would normally be considered by the Panel or given significant weight in the absence of other moving considerations.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re Richardson-Merrell, Inc., 588 F. Supp. 1448, 1449 (J.P.M.L. 1984).
